subject: Gardening
title: The Species Problem
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Species Problem.

hook.text: Ask ten botanists to define 'species' and you'll get at least twelve answers. The concept is messier than it seems.

buildup.text: Animals are often defined as species when they can't interbreed. But plants hybridize constantly.

discovery.text: Polyploidyâ€”doubling chromosome setsâ€”creates new plant species instantly. It happens regularly in nature.

twist.text: Wheat has six chromosome sets from three ancestor species. By any strict definition, it's not one species.

climax.text: The species concept is a human convenience. Nature draws boundaries in pencil, not ink.

quiz.question: Why is defining 'species' especially difficult in plants?
options: Plants can hybridize freely and create new species through polyploidy
Plants don't have DNA that can be sequenced reliably
Plant species change their characteristics every generation
